evidence.text:
Person A: It really was. Sometimes I swear they don’t realize I have a life and would rather be home with you guys than typing up reports at 11pm on a Thursday from my hotel room.
Person A: I thought you hated Book Babies?
Person B: Oh I do. It was an accident, truth be told, but he loved it.
Person A: You’re still alive, ya ol’ furball?
Person B: She is the cat who will never die. Even though nobody really pays any attention to her anymore. Baby, no! Don’t chase the cat.
Person B: Speaking of furballs - I’m like... I don’t know.
Person A: What?
Person B: No. I shouldn’t have brought it up. I’m just having some odd side effects maybe of perimenopause? I’m not sure. Weird hair sprouting up?
Person A: You talking about your nipples?
Person B: No! Lower back. And kind of my toes too. I don’t know. I just feel off. I feel like I have this heightened sense of smell - kind of like when I was pregnant. The cat’s butt smells disgusting to me.
Person A: That’s not just you.
Person B: And my teeth seem to be getting sharper. Look!
Person A: Oh yeah. Definitely. Your teeth look so weird. This is real and not in your head.
Person A: I’m sorry, but honey you always think something is wrong with you.
Person B: Well, that’s the thing about being a hypochondriac - one day I will be right! And then you’ll be sorry.
Person B: I can’t remember the last time I washed this shirt. *
Person A: I never washed any of my clothes * for all of college. You’re just * like a bachelor.
Person B: I mean, it’s just like... what’s the point? I always hated hard pants. I’m giving in to just a soft- pants lifestyle.
Person A: You’re living the dream.
Person B: I’m the housewife I never wanted to be! You know what’s the hardest part? It’s like I’m on suicide watch and I can’t look away for even a second. Or he might stick a fork into a light socket, or like walk off a cliff. Why does he want to kill himself? It’s so much more mentally exhausting than I expected.
Person A: It’s better than leaving him with those awful ladies at the awful daycare, right?
Person B: I guess. That was heartbreaking.
Person B: If you wake him up I will rip your throat out.
Person A: I thought this is what you wanted. No more long hours at the gallery and crying while you pumped your boobs in a bathroom.
Person B: I did, I do. But maybe I need to find a part-time job or something? So I don’t lose my mind.
Person A: It’s just the math doesn’t totally add up. The likelihood of you making more than we would have to pay a sitter-
Person B: I know. And there aren’t really part time gallery jobs. Or part time nannies.
Person A: Right.
Person B: Maybe when he starts school.
Person A: Yeah. You just gotta hold on till Kindergarten.
Person B: Then I think - how dare I complain? What a gift - to get to be with my baby all day long. I should be grateful- on the scale of people who have things to complain about I’m at the bottom. I’m just a fucking privileged white lady who gets to stay home and make cookies all day.
Person A: Do you make cookies?
Person B: Not once.
Person A: I would kill to get to stay home with him every day, for what that’s worth.
Person B: You think that. But I can assure you, you would not.
Person B: HEY! His fucking binky! Do you not hear him? The husband wakes, totally confused, and she turns her back * to them to let him figure it out. He fumbles and puts the * binky back in his son’s mouth, who quiets.
Person A: Did you make coffee?
Person B: Not yet - will you do it?
Person A: Uh... sure. Is it two scoops?
Person B: I do three.
Person A: So, last night... you were kind of a-
Person B: Bitch?
Person A: You said it not me.
Person B: Yep. Night bitch. I am Nightbitch.
Person B: I sort of said it like that so that he could see I’m a good sport. I’m not like uptight, or not able to poke fun at myself. But once I said it, I knew the horrible truth. Nightbitch has always been there.
Person A: What’s next?
Person B: Bath time.
Person A: I’ll do it. Let’s go little dude.
Person B: Thank you.
Person B: He is a good man. He is. He wasn’t always so literal and cut off-

Person B: It’s just - when you’re gone, I do this by myself every day.
Person B: Say ‘bye-bye dada’
Person A: Bye-bye dada!
Person A: Honey- I...
Person B: I know. I know. But I’m telling you... it’s like I have a tail - you know those babies who are born with a tail? A fucking- Sorry, a freakin- tail.

Person B: You are free to go to the market with our son and pick some up if you want. And while you’re there get me some tampons, ok? I’m about to start bleeding and I have a feeling this one is going to be a doozy!

Person B: This is the first shower I have had this week. I’ve been to the supermarket three times, but I haven’t gotten to wash my body in at least four days. So clearly I didn’t realize that we were out of milk or I would have gotten some.
Person B: You are free to go to the market with our son and pick some up if you want. And while you’re there get me some tampons, ok? I’m about to start bleeding and I have a feeling this one is going to be a doozy!

Person A: Nooooo.
Person A: I just... don’t want one more thing needing me or touching me.
Person B: Uh huh. Pretty harsh.
Person A: I’m sorry, I’m just in so much fucking pain, you have no idea.
Person B: Oh, gotcha. Sorry.

Person A: It’s under the bed! You wanna see what I got you?
Person A: Now baby. Doggies go to night night in their beds right?
Person A: And do doggies use binkies? Noooo.
Person A: Night night doggie.
Person A: Dare to be stupid, dare to be stupid. What did I say? Dare to be stupid. Tell me, what did I say? Dare to be stupid. It’s alright. Dare to be stupid. We can be stupid all night.

Person A: Yes. He wanted to be domesticated. I was against that.
Person B: What now?
Person A: But I haven’t had to lie with him for hours on end to get him to fall asleep - I just give a little growl and he goes to bed on his own. Without a B.I.N.K.Y.
Person A: For him? Or for you?
Person B: You have to see how weird this is!
Person A: No I don’t. What’s the problem? He’s sleeping, which means I’m sleeping for the first time in two fucking years. We are getting so much exercise - I’m not waking up with pain in my back anymore. We’re having fun. When did you become so uptight?
Person A: A woman, when pushed to her limit, will call on all her faculties to care for her young.
Person A: This is where my son rolled in the grass -sweet hot breath, little banana cream breath. And mine. Mine when I was... human.
Person B: Oh honey - do you feel left out?

Person A: Kitty! I’m going to throw you onto the roof and let you starve to death up there.
Person B: Maybe a chicken hawk will swoop down and grab her with its talons while she’s up there.
Person B: Then take her up into the sky and drop her from a great height into a deep quarry where heaving mining equipment with caterpillar treads will repeatedly run over her broken corpse.

Person B: I am just a mom now. I should focus on being the best mom I can be - enjoying these moments with him, because this isn’t going to last. He’s growing up so fast.
Person A: That’s true.
Person B: And being an artist is such a silly, self-absorbed thing to be. It’s truly an embarrassing job to say out loud. What am I, six? Picking between an artist or a princess?
Person A: Okay. If that’s what you want.
Person B: That’s what I want.
Person B: I’m taking your advice. I’m making a plan for the week. A schedule for us.
Person A: Oh. Good.
Person B: See- Monday is gymnastics at the play space. Tuesday is Book Babies at the library- my fave. Wednesday: mommy/baby yoga in the park. Thursday is free day and Friday is Tyke Hike!
Person A: Wow. Okay.
Person B: I mean, if I’m gonna do it, I should just commit. Right?
Person A: Right.
Person B: And you remember that I said I would meet up with my grad school friends in the city tonight, right?
Person A: Yes. I’m babysitting.
Person B: It’s not babysitting when it’s your own kid.
Person A: Whatever. You know what I mean. I’m on bedtime duty. And you are going to go have a grown up dinner.
Person B: Yep. At 9 pm. Four hours later than I usually eat.
Person A: Yowsa. You look nice.
Person A: Nobody in this fucking family can clean their own butts.

Person A: Oh god, she does that when she has a shit stuck on her butt. This- fucking cat. Someone has to wash her.
Person A: Come on! I can’t. I never get to go out.

Person B: Okay, fine - I got a little drunk. It was really weird seeing all those people again after all this time. It made me feel like shit. So I drank my dinner and missed the * last bus. I’m sorry. *
Person B: Because I’m not doing anything with my life. Because they think I’m just a mother now. Which I am. I mean, I know I am. But they think it’s pathetic and it made me feel pathetic.

Person A: They don’t have any clue. They don’t have kids. They don’t know what they’re missing.
Person A: At some point you’re going to have to start accepting that we’ve made some choices over the years that landed us here. I don’t know about you, but I wouldn’t trade those choices for the world.

Person B: So quick. No protestations from you! And I keep running over that conversation in my head. Because it would have been so nice for you to encourage me at least a little bit not to quit. Tell me that I was good at what I did, and it would be a shame to give it up. Say that I would return to it one day. But you just smiled.
Person B: Because somewhere you were getting what you’ve always wanted. For me to be a stay at home mom.
Person B: Just like your mother. And her mother. A sweet deal for you. You have your job and I have mine. Only my job has no pay and no appreciation and no vacation days and includes washing your underwear.
Person B: You feel trapped? Do you have any fucking clue how trapped I am? I’ve found myself in a fucking 1950s marriage somehow and I have no idea who I am anymore and all I do is take care of our son and you and the fucking cat- before I killed her.
Person B: You’re right. I agreed to it, but I had no fucking idea what I was agreeing to. I didn’t realize I would feel like a single parent who has zero help and has to give up my dreams to take care of everyone! I don’t even know who I am anymore!
Person B: HOW CAN YOU NOT SEE ME? I’m wilting while you’re out succeeding.
Person A: If you were so fucking unhappy why didn’t you tell me? You expect me to read your mind? If you tell me that everything is fine, then I think that everything is fine. If you tell me that you want to quit being an artist and stay home with our son, and I say ok, I think I’m supporting you. That’s just some passive-aggressive bullshit.

Person B: This agreement we made, that I would stay home and you would go to work isn’t working for me anymore. I need... space. I don’t even know how to - I don’t know who I am or what I need. I need to dig around in the dark and find myself again.
Person B: No. I don’t. But I had no clue what we were actually getting into. If I could go back in time, I would have made us sit down and work out a more equitable way to do this parenting thing.
Person A: I would have been open to that.
Person B: I’m sorry.
Person A: Me too.

Person B: There’s my baby!!
Person A: We had a good night, didn’t we, dude? It was hard. I’m not gonna lie. It was... hard. He missed you. And my place is... a little weird. Sterile.
Person B: Sure. I get it.
Person A: How was your first night alone?
Person B: It was really wonderful, actually. I think I have an idea for a new project. I’m just really focused. It’s amazing how efficient I can be now that I never have any time. Give me an hour and I’m doing more than I used to do in a week.
Person B: You want some hashbrowns, baby?
Person B: So I’ll drop him off Friday morning?
Person A: Okay. Yeah. I need to get some toys at my place. He was so bored. And maybe a stuffy or something?
Person B: That’s a good idea. I’ll send you the link for that dinosaur he loves. You could get him one for your place. And I’ll pack more for him too.
Person A: Okay yeah.
Person A: He’s really sweet. But he’s also not used to me. I kinda felt like he thought he’d been kidnapped.
Person B: That will change. This is gonna be good for both of you.
Person A: He’s like ‘who is this weird man living in this sad apartment complex with all the other sad men?’ I swear the whole place is newly divorced dads. All these kids at the pool kind of just confused - not a mom in sight.
Person B: I just picture all the kids getting sunburned because nobody remembers the sunscreen.
Person A: Oh man, I didn’t even think of sunscreen.
Person B: See you Friday?
Person A: Yep.
Person B: Okay! What do we want to do today? I missed you so much.
Person B: May we pet your dog?
Person B: We love dogs!
Person B: That one?
Person B: May we chase your dog?
Person B: It’s so cool right?
Person B: You know that I love being your mom, right?
Person B: It makes me so happy. You are a wonderful kid.
Person B: I want to go back and grab you by the shoulders...
Person B: ...And scream at you ‘you’re amazing! You’re my mother!
Person B: Go to Europe. Insist on your joy! Time is short...
Person B: ...Don’t just do it for you, do it for me too!’
Person B: I always thought motherhood was sort of a weak state of being - like very basic and passive. But motherhood is a far more primal active thing than that.
Person B: It is probably the most violent experience a human can have aside from death itself.
Person B: A child’s first act is violence against the woman who created it. Yet still the mother loves the child with the most powerful love known in this universe. Miriam is a wild boar, Liz is a moose. And Norma is there as a wise owl.
Person B: This thing comes from us. It rips its way out of us, literally tears us in two, in a wash of blood and shit and piss.

Person A: You are the giver of life to our * son, and I should have been so much * more ... I don’t know what. I * should have given that so much more * respect. *
Person A: I should have told you to not give * this up. I really fucked up. And I * am so sorry. *
Person B: Thank you. Thank you for being * willing to say that. *
Person A: You can’t give this up - you have * too much to say. You’re so weird * and I love you. *
Person B: I love you. *
Person B: Really? You sure? *
Person A: Are you kidding me? This is your night. Please go enjoy it. I’m going to go hug our sleeping child, and think about what magic it is that brought him into the world. *
Person A: I’m proud of you. *

Person A: This must be what it is to be an animal. To look at another and say ‘I am so much that other thing that we are part of one another’.
Person B: I want salmon.

Person B: This is how it’s always been and how it will continue to be. From outside their blanket cave, we see the warm light of their game, their shadows look like real bears in the cave - the sounds of bear roars fill the warm bedroom, which is now transformed into a forest with trees having sprouted up all around the tent.
Person B: AHHHHH! I can’t. I can’t do it.
